Name: Anthe
Description: They call it the city of flowers, but the flowers are crystals, spiral matrices grown on the walls of Anthean caves. The inhabitants of Anthe are at least partly crystal too: they call it "going sharp." Becoming more perfect, and clearer, and colder.

DefaultEvent.Name: Rumours and extrapolations
DefaultEvent.Description: Access to Anthe is restricted by type of sharpness: those who are sharp in the ears do not necessarily mingle with the sharp-tongued. As for the inhabitants who are sharp throughout their full bodies, they don't circulate much. There is said to be a cavern, broad and shallow-floored, where the perfectly sharp grow old together. They aren't capable of anyone else's company any more â€” at least, that's what you're told, and you can hardly go and ask. At any rate they are more like growing crystals than like people, slowly expanding and bonding with the rock.

ChildBranches.Name: Gather a port report on Anthe
ChildBranches.Description: The Admiralty will want stories of this place.

DefaultEvent.Name: Those who go sharp
DefaultEvent.Description:
The inhabitants of Anthe go sharp. Not all at once, but piece by piece, they turn to crystal. They sort themselves by sharpness, too: the sharp-handed cluster with others of their kind, ignoring the keen-footed and the brittle-waisted.

To progress through Anthe is to take on more and more of these attributes, to enter the deeper chambers restricted by sharp-style. Choose which chambers you would most like to discover. The Antheans speak of a woman named Rosina, dying of a curious disease and sequestered among the sharp-spleened.

ChildBranches.Name: Study the chambers of Anthe
ChildBranches.Description: Wander where you can. Gain a preliminary understanding of the place.

DefaultEvent.Name: Taking root
DefaultEvent.Description: The Blemmigan scampers across the spiked floor of the first cave. It finds a crevice and settles in. How long before it begins to go clear? Will its stem turn to crystal first, or its cap?

ChildBranches.Name: Free a blemmigan
ChildBranches.Description: Perhaps it would find the place congenial.

ChildBranches.Name: Reset Anthe Everything
ChildBranches.Description: Secret reset.

DefaultEvent.Name: Ice crystals
DefaultEvent.Description: The air gets chillier as you approach, and there are patches of frost on the walls.

ChildBranches.Name: Visit Rosina in her Chambers
ChildBranches.Description: She is both healer and patient, convalescing in an ice bath among the sharp-spleened. The Antheans speak of her often.

DefaultEvent.Name: This sharp flourishing is not for him
DefaultEvent.Description:
The Femur and Lung is a drinking house two passageways along from the Bone-Barrow. The tables are crowded with miners and fungers. The Clay Man is ignored by the company, unwelcome.

He shows you the palms of his hands, where triclinic crystals grow every which way, ragged and disorganised. It is difficult for clay to go sharp. Sometimes it succeeds, but the failures are awkward.

"POLYTHREME MAKE IT CLAY AGAIN. HEAL EVERYTHING."

ChildBranches.Name: Chase down a Polythreme Exile
ChildBranches.Description: He is lurking at the back of the Femur and Lung.

DefaultEvent.Name: They know the contact you're seeking...
DefaultEvent.Description:
...but he's not here. "He's gone sharp in the liver, no doubt," says the woman with the venom-ruby ring. "But he is also a student of codes and encryptions, and that has taken him to the chambers of the Tongue."

The man next to her makes a face. "Those people are all terribly rude," he says. "Stay here with us."

ChildBranches.Name: Gather flourishing intelligence among the sharp-livered
ChildBranches.Description: This is where spies gather, after all.

DefaultEvent.Name: A broad tunnel
DefaultEvent.Description: The vines that hang along the tunnel walls are all nurtured crystal. Their fruit glitters. Their fallen leaves wobble without breaking underfoot. In time the tunnel opens out to a vista, a grand cavern...

ChildBranches.Name: Visit the garden of the Sharpest
ChildBranches.Description: You are almost all sharp, after all.

DefaultEvent.Name: Like talking to statues
DefaultEvent.Description:
You reveal a recent London tale of corruption, folly, and spite, of incompetent people prospering from their incompetence, and kind people suffering for their kindness, and perfectly good supplies wasted.

Your listeners' faces do not change. Their eyelids do not quiver. In exchange, they tell you several infuriating tales you had not heard before. One even rewards you with fuel. "I am never zailing back to London," she says. "Your ztory has reminded me why." Candlelight winks in the tip of her tongue.

ChildBranches.Name: Share an enraging story you picked up in London
ChildBranches.Description: Something to share over drinks. The other sharp-spleened Antheans will greatly enjoy having no reaction.

DefaultEvent.Name: A pleasant lassitude
DefaultEvent.Description: They drink from geodes. They compare notes on the terroir. When everyone is thoroughly intoxicated, they roll out a crate of dried, honeyed cakes. "The captain who brought it went sharp in the bowels. She doesn't eat now. Help yourself."

ChildBranches.Name: Contribute to the celebration
ChildBranches.Description: The crystal-livered drink and drink. Unquestionably they'd trade ordinary food for your mushroom wine.

DefaultEvent.Name: Plenty of bandages
DefaultEvent.Description:
She went clear in the skin to prevent bruising in the embrace of a mineralised wife. 

"I thought I was rising to a challenge. I thought I should become a stronger person." Then she laughs. She does not offer the rest of the story, but you already know more than you would like.

She wishes to reach Venderbight without undue attention from strangers. She has a pile of bandages and a coffin she has built herself from scavenged wood. But she will need your help to do the rest.

ChildBranches.Name: Offer passage to the Tomb Colonies
ChildBranches.Description: There is a clear-skinned traveler who wishes to make an escape.

DefaultEvent.Name: Learning and rumour
DefaultEvent.Description: Consult the woman with the cubical eyes. Learn how to accept the blessings that Anthe offers. Determine what is best for yourself, and whose companionship you seek in the bubble-caverns.

ChildBranches.Name: Consider your own condition
ChildBranches.Description: Should you go sharp? Or have you already taken on sharpness that you now regret?

DefaultEvent.Name: A familiar stair
DefaultEvent.Description: Your feet have learned where the treacherous risers may be found.

ChildBranches.Name: Visit Rosina in her Chambers
ChildBranches.Description: The rumour is that she has resumed seeing patients and working on the mystery of animescence.

DefaultEvent.Name: A flawless curriculum vitae
DefaultEvent.Description:
You describe the woman she was, as you observed her. Your description is apt and unflinching. You speak of her manners, her erudition, her inability to protect herself at the last. You omit the question of whether you killed her. No one asks you for an account of her final minutes.

When you are done, the Antheans reward you with her notes and logs. No one else here wishes to preserve them.

ChildBranches.Name: Deliver an unfeeling eulogy to the late Rosina
ChildBranches.Description: The sharp-skinned, sharp-tongued Antheans would appreciate remarks without sentiment.

DefaultEvent.Name: The speed of unhappiness
DefaultEvent.Description:
You follow. The Clay Man is moving fast, down several corridors, towards the section of Anthe reserved for the bone-sharp. A sight like that would not be at all extraordinary in London, but most of the inhabitants of Anthe seem complacent, possibly even indolent. Hardly anyone is ever in a hurry.

The Man ducks into the Bone-Barrow. A person would be unwise to follow unless they had considerable confidence in their own skeleton.

ChildBranches.Name: Follow a Polythreme Exile
ChildBranches.Description: A hulking clay figure is visible through the smoke. It moves away through the opposite door.

DefaultEvent.Name: The Gallery of Axes
DefaultEvent.Description:
The Hooded Anthean is impressed with your offering. It will make a keen and pitiless blade. She tells you stories in exchange: about her travels, her duties, the people and animals she has hunted. She even presents you with a huge curved tooth: corroboration for her story. She doesn't need it any longer.

You are careful not to look under her hood.

ChildBranches.Name: Trade Heartmetal in the Gallery of Axes
ChildBranches.Description: Strength and a resistance to pity: these are essential for an executioner. And they need, of course, the best weaponry.

DefaultEvent.Name: An exchange of provisions
DefaultEvent.Description:
Trays circulate with every possible indulgence. Brandy from the surface. Cigars from Rosegate. Coffee. A drink made with squeezed oranges, rum, and smoldering cinnamon. 

The honey, however, is hard to keep in sufficient supply. They welcome your contribution with lavish rewards.

ChildBranches.Name: Stop by the Smokehouse
ChildBranches.Description: A hedonistic sanctuary for those who have gone sharp in both liver and lung. Trade them some Prisoner's Honey for essential supplies.

DefaultEvent.Name: Above revulsion
DefaultEvent.Description:
Contact toxins do not trouble their skin. Serpents cannot pierce them. Venoms milked from the fang cannot make them ill. A mycological poison is merely a challenge to their knowledge of toadstool terroir. 

The club is run by a large jolly Anthean who poses daily challenges. He offers your Relic in buffet, and the members find it a very acceptable test. You're allowed to collect your own plate from the feast.

ChildBranches.Name: Visit the Dauntless Palate
ChildBranches.Description: Offer a Lamentable Relic as a challenge to those sharp in liver, skin, and tongue.

DefaultEvent.Name: Finished. Tidy. Neat.
DefaultEvent.Description:
A Clay Man who's gone sharp is a Clay Man you can trust. Respectable, solid boned, patient. Incapable of rage or bad manners. That is why they come here: to be certified trustworthy, to show that they're suitable for better jobs and better treatment.

The Travertine Vault is full of such men, sitting patiently in rows, waiting for the crystals to grow. They don't talk. You put your six in the back row. They pay you as they would have paid you in London. And this other item, this thing that looked like a bench? You can have that too. It's in the way.

ChildBranches.Name: Set down Clay Men in the Travertine Vault
ChildBranches.Description: Clay Men come from Polythreme to learn sharpness of bone and spleen.

DefaultEvent.Name: Inside a great shell
DefaultEvent.Description:
The concert hall was once the shell of an impossible oyster. Now its surfaces are clean and iridescent, and the singers of Anthe perform. They can hold a note - a perfect, shapely note - for longer than ought to be possible.

They sing the Song of Broken Hulls until it threatens to shatter the oyster shell. The performers are excited and full of questions. The song is brutal, sharp, and cold! Where did you get it? Who wrote it?

They reward you as well as they can, with gossip and food.

ChildBranches.Name: Sell your song of Broken Hulls to the Singers in the Shell
ChildBranches.Description: Lung and Tongue are both crystal, the better to sing.

DefaultEvent.Name: "So you've been to Dahut."
DefaultEvent.Description:
Bleak smiles. "I lived there once, and loved mortals. But a traveller came to us who had gone sharp in the brain. She could not be seduced. The prison would not hold her. She came to Midsummer Festival one day and Midwinter the next. When she left us, I followed her back to Anthe. But she is still ahead of me: she's gone sharp the rest of the way, now, and she is growing in the Garden like an oak tree, while I am still waiting." 

Then the Drownie offers you something. "If you go again to Dahut, take this. It will keep you clear."

ChildBranches.Name: Offer your Drownie Love-song to the Drownies in the Cave-Pool
ChildBranches.Description: They keep apart from other Antheans, but they have gone sharp in their own way.

DefaultEvent.Name: Information? In great supply
DefaultEvent.Description: Your quarry answers your question in macaronic riddle-verse. A lot of it isn't in English. Some of it isn't even in human words. You extract enough that you can carry a reply back to the Khanate, but to understand it yourself? Less so. Has your spy gone sharp in the brain as well as the liver and tongue?

ChildBranches.Name: Seek your spy
ChildBranches.Description: ...in the Granite Corridor, where the most linguistically skilled assassins may be found. [You will always receive information towards your quest, but may also gain a bonus.]

DefaultEvent.Name: Calm reflection
DefaultEvent.Description:
You read aloud a scene concerning a lady and her Rubbery Companion. No one giggles. No one smirks, or gasps, or shifts in their seat. They all listen with fixed attention to the details. From time to time, someone interrupts with a correction of the participants' technique. 

After your reading, they bring you refreshments. "It's exhausting work reading through all that," says a monk gravely, and he passes you a platter of cured fluke meats.

ChildBranches.Name: Lead the critique of some Romantic Literature
ChildBranches.Description: It will amuse the company to correct the more lurid scenes, with special attention to anatomical accuracy and selection of metaphor. [This will exchange Romantic Literature for Supplies, and may gain you an improved edition if you are fortunate.]

DefaultEvent.Name: Alas
DefaultEvent.Description: You're quick and you're vicious, but the others in this chamber have been playing these games for much longer than you have. They know each other's foibles; they can make each insult stick. You fight to an honourable failure in the second round.

ChildBranches.Name: Take the stage, spitting
ChildBranches.Description: Antheans clear in spleen, skin, and tongue insult one another for sport. There is a solacefruit for second place. First place is not rewarded.

DefaultEvent.Name: Less than impressive
DefaultEvent.Description: Your skeleton bears a lot of the pressure, and your muscles and ligaments have been strengthened too. But even so, there's so much rock to bear that your shoulders are not up to the task, and you have to hand off the burden to another Anthean earlier than you would like.

ChildBranches.Name: Practice holding the ceiling in place
ChildBranches.Description: Care to bet on your strength against the other denizens of the Bone-Barrow? [On success, this will reduce terror.]

DefaultEvent.Name: Future plans
DefaultEvent.Description:
"I'm going sharp in the lungs next," says a woman in a deep red gown. "They say you can smoke all day long and never develop a cough."

The gentleman next to her looks amused and takes the cognac out of her hand. "I'm sure you'll find yourself very much at home."

ChildBranches.Name: Listen in on the nearest group of people
ChildBranches.Description: What do they speak of here? [You will always hear something. It's just a question of what.]

DefaultEvent.Name: Out, out
DefaultEvent.Description: There are many of them, and only one of you. Under other circumstances you might have been able to capture them without casualties. In the present particular circumstances, you are only able to drive them out of Anthe. But the Sharp appreciate your work nonetheless. There is nothing so irritating to the crystalline mind as a gaggle of sweaty poets swooning in the corridors.

ChildBranches.Name: Clear out the Conflagranti
ChildBranches.Description: Rosina's Onlookers are everywhere in Anthe, sighing over poetry and languishing in feverish postures. The Antheans cannot endure them.

DefaultEvent.Name: Something close to mutiny
DefaultEvent.Description: The former coal-miners speak of masters and cruelty and insufficient pay. They talk about what's due to bad captains, and the rightful fate of those that give dangerous orders. By the time they're done with the topic, you've one less crewmember willing to follow your commands.

ChildBranches.Name: Mingle with Hurriers, Getters and Thrusters
ChildBranches.Description: They used to be coal-miners. Now they are impervious to coal gas or flooding. They might give you something; they might lure your crew away.

DefaultEvent.Name: No luck
DefaultEvent.Description: Your enquiries are exhaustive - the Philanthropist's husband is not here. You can cross this port off your list. [Check your journal for reminders about where the Philanthropist's husband might be.]

ChildBranches.Name: Search for the Fierce Philanthropist's husband
ChildBranches.Description: Has he been here, among the glittering edges and the shivering reflections?
